The utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) to synthesize various chemicals is of great importance. Herein, various azaphosphatranes and silver salts were applied to catalyze the carboxylative cyclization of CO2 and propargylic alcohols to prepare α-methylene cyclic carbonates. The influences of catalyst structures, solvents and reaction parameters on catalytic performance were systematically studied. The combination of tris(4-methoxybenzyl) azaphosphatranes (PMB-AZAP) and Ag2O with molar ratio of 0.5:1 gave α-methylene cyclic carbonate in the yield of >99 % at room temperature. Meanwhile, other azaphosphatranes (i-Bu-AZAP, Me-AZAP) gave the product in slightly lower yields. The mechanism exploration revealed that PMB-AZAP and Ag2O formed a silver complex PMB-AZAP-Ag during the reaction, which could synergistically catalyze carboxylative cyclization reaction with PMB-AZAP, resulting in a high product yield. In contrast, AgCl or AgNO3 couldn't react with PMB-AZAP to form silver complexes, and the corresponding catalytic system had no activity. The difference of the catalytic performance indicated that PMB-AZAP-Ag was a key active species for the carboxylative cyclization reaction. The in situ NMR studies concretely demonstrated that PMB-AZAP could activate propargylic alcohols through hydrogen bonding. Furthermore, the catalytic system had good substrate generality. The PMB-AZAP/Ag2O was also applied for the one-pot reaction of propargylic alcohol, CO2 and CH3OH, affording the β-carbonyl carbonate with yield of 80 % at CH3OH/propargylic alcohols ratio of 20:1. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Azaphosphatranes Carbon dioxide fixation Propargylic alcohols Carboxylative cyclization Silver complex Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The emission of CO2 has attracted the attention both industrially and academically as it is widely considered as a global-warming gas [1,2]. Meanwhile, CO2 is a cheap and abundant renewable C1 resource and can be used to synthesize various chemicals, such as organic carbonates, polymers, alcohols, urea derivatives, and formic acid [3–8]. The carboxylative cyclization of CO2 and propargylic alcohols was an important method for CO2 utilization, and the synthesized α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates could be widely used in the pharmaceutical chemistry and organic synthesis intermediates, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, and inert solvents [9–12]. At present, many catalysts reported for the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols and CO2, including the transition-metal compounds (Ag, Cu, Zn, Pd, Co), metal-free systems (e.g., ionic liquids, P-ylide-CO2 adduct, N-heterocyclic carbene and N-heterocyclic olefins) [13–18]. Among them, the silver-based catalytic systems had attracted widespread interest due to their good catalytic performance under mild conditions. Silver salts such as AgOAc, AgI, and silver sulfadiazine in combining with various co-catalysts including organic bases, quaternary ammonium salts, phosphine ligands, could achieve good yields (91–99 %) and selectivities (>99 %) of cyclic carbonates under mild reaction temperature (25–80 °C) [19–25]. The heterogeneous silver catalysts mainly included supported silver-complexes and silver-nanoparticles. Silver-complexes loaded on carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [26], polystyrene (PS) [27] and metal organic frameworks [28] were applied as catalysts to efficiently catalyze the conversion of CO2 due to the synergistic effect between functional matrix and metal species. Silver-nanoparticles supported on sulfonated macroreticular resin (AgNPs/SMR) [29], reduced graphene oxide (Ag-rGO) [30], nanotubular porous porphyrin-based network (Ag@NT-PPN) [31] and triazinetriamine-based porous organic polymer (AgNPs@TzTa-POP) [32] were selected as catalysts and the moderate to good yield of cyclic carbonates were obtained in the presence of organic bases as co-catalysts. Regrettably, the slight aggregation of silver particles after recycling lead to a decrease in catalytic activity. The above supported silver catalysts all used polymers or macromolecular structures as solid supports, which allowed the introduction of various CO2-philic functional species inside their structures to obtain more active, functional, and reusable catalysts. Despite significant advances on catalysts in the past decade, the development of efficient and novel CO2 carboxylative cyclization catalytic systems remains a challenge. The azaphosphatranes are acidic counterparts of the proazaphosphatrane superbases (Verkade's superbases) and have well-defined tricyclics around the phosphorus atom [33]. Recently, the azaphosphatranes were applied as effective catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides [34–36]. The azaphosphatranes could effectively activate CO2 by insertion of CO2 into the P-N bond of azaphosphatranes to form a tricyclic phosphoryl-carbamate structure. The azaphosphatranes with bulkier substituents (e.g. p-methoxybenzyl, neo-pentyl) were beneficial for forming intramolecular hydrogen bonds with the +P-H moiety, providing a cavity above the reactive center to protect the tricyclic phosphoryl-carbamate species. Besides, the azaphosphatranes with bulkier substituents could also react with Ag2O to form silver complexes due to their large cone angles and dissociation rate [37,38]. With the advantage of activating CO2 and easily forming silver complexes with Ag2O, the azaphosphatranes might be potential catalysts for the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohol and CO2. Herein, we presented a strategy of azaphosphatranes/Ag2O system synergistically catalyzed the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols and CO2, resulting in high yield (>99 %) and selectivity (>99 %) of the α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates at room temperature. The reaction mechanism revealed that PMB-AZAP and Ag2O formed a silver complex PMB-AZAP-Ag during the reaction, which was a key active species for catalyzing carboxylative cyclization. The PMB-AZAP-Ag and PMB-AZAP had synergistic catalytic effects on the substrates through the coordination of carbon-carbon triple bond with PMB-AZAP-Ag and hydrogen-bond interaction of hydroxyl groups with PMB-AZAP. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Azaphosphatranes/Ag2O synergistic catalyzed the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohol and CO2 The carboxylative cyclization reaction of 2-methyl-3-butynl-2-ol (1a) and CO2 to generate α-methylene cyclic carbonate (2a) was used as the model reaction in catalytic systems (Table 1 ). When Ag2O or tris(4-methoxybenzyl) azaphosphatranes (PMB-AZAP) was used as catalyst alone, 2a was not observed in the reaction mixture (Entry 1,2). Interestingly, the combination of PMB-AZAP and Ag2O with different ratios of 0.5:1 to 1:1 and 2:1 gave 2a in the yields of >99 %, 95 % and 91 %, respectively (Entry 3-5). The superior activity of azaphosphatranes/Ag2O system implied the synergistic effect between PMB-AZAP and Ag2O. Other azaphosphatranes with smaller substituents such as isobutyl (i-Bu-AZAP) and methyl (Me-AZAP) combining with Ag2O also gave 2a in slightly lower yields of 92 % and 85 %, respectively (Entry 6,7). The difference in activity might be due the larger substituents would provide spatial protection for the active site, thereby improving the stability of the catalyst [34,35]. The effect of solvents was also investigated under optimized catalyst system. In high polar aprotic solvents such as DMF and CH3CN, the catalytic system performed well and afforded 2a in the yields of 90–96 % (Entry 8,9). However, in the protic solvents such as H2O and CH3OH, 2a was not observed (Entry 10,11). The significant difference might ascribe to that the hydroxyl group in these solvents affected the recognition and activation of hydroxyl group of propargylic alcohol by the catalysts [39,40]. The combinations of other silver salts (e.g., AgCl, AgNO3) and PMB-AZAP had no catalytic activity (<3 % yields) (Entry 12, 13). To reveal the significant differences of the silver salts, the reactions of azaphosphatranes with Ag2O, AgCl and AgNO3 were performed, respectively, and the obtained reaction mixture were analyzed by 31P NMR and 1H NMR (Fig. 1 , Fig. S1, S2). In 31P NMR spectra of the reaction mixture of Ag2O and PMB-AZAP, a distinct quadruple peak appeared at δ = 112.2 ppm, with the coupling constants of J1 (31P-109Ag) = 1299 Hz and J2 (31P-107Ag) = 1128 Hz (Fig. 1). The splitting of phosphorus was caused by two isotopes of silver (109Ag and 107Ag). The observation of new formed phosphorus species indicated that a silver complex (PMB-AZAP-Ag) was generated which was consistent with our previous report [37]. As shown in 1H NMR (Fig. S1), new signal peaks (δ = 7.34, 4.30 and 2.75 ppm) belonged to the benzene ring, N-CH2 and N(CH2)2N on PMB-AZAP-Ag. By comparing the peak areas of proton at the same position on PMB-AZAP-Ag and PMB-AZAP, the molar fractions of PMB-AZAP-Ag and PMB-AZAP were 0.65 and 0.35, respectively. The two-component mixture was named [PMB-AZAP]0.35[PMB-AZAP-Ag]0.65. In contrast, there were not any new peaks observed in the reaction mixtures of AgCl or AgNO3 and PMB-AZAP, indicating that PMB-AZAP could not react with acidic AgCl or AgNO3 to form silver complexes (Fig. S2). To further reveal the catalytic active species in the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols and CO2, [PMB-AZAP]0.35[PMB-AZAP-Ag]0.65 was applied as catalyst and achieved high yield (>99 %) of 2a under optimized conditions. These results indicated that the silver complex PMB-AZAP-Ag formed by the reaction of PMB-AZAP and Ag2O was the key active species for the catalytic carboxylative cyclization reactions. The interaction between 1a and PMB-AZAP/Ag2O was also investigated by in situ 1H NMR (Fig. S3). The sharp peak of 1a at δ = 5.31 ppm was attributed to the hydroxyl proton (Fig. S3a). After adding Ag2O, this peak did not show any obvious changes (Fig. S3b). However, after adding PMB-AZAP, this peak was widened significantly (Fig. S3c). The significant change of peak shape implied that the formation of hydrogen bonds between hydroxyl of 1a and PMB-AZAP tertiary amine [25]. Similar observation was also obtained in the mixture of 1a and PMB-AZAP/Ag2O (Fig. S3d). On the basis of the formation of AZAP-Ag and in situ NMR, the possible mechanism of the carboxylative cyclization reaction synergistically catalyzed by azaphosphatranes/Ag2O was proposed (Fig. 2 ). Firstly, AZAP-Ag was formed by reaction of azaphosphatranes and Ag2O, resulting in a co-catalytic system of azaphosphatranes and AZAP-Ag. Then, the tertiary amine of azaphosphatranes activated the hydroxyl group of propargylic alcohol through hydrogen bond to generate intermediate I. The activated hydroxyl groups attacked CO2, and AZAP-Ag activated carbon carbon triple bond in propargylic alcohol to form intermediate II. The negatively charged oxygen atom attacked the inner alkyne carbon of propargylic alcohol to form a five-membered ring III. Finally, α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates were formed and the azaphosphatranes and AZAP-Ag were released to participate in the next cycle. 2.2 Optimization of reaction parameters The effect of the reaction parameters, including reaction time, catalyst amount, CO2 pressure and solvent amount on the carboxylative cyclization reaction over PMB-AZAP/Ag2O were systematically investigated (Fig. 3 ). With the extension of reaction time from 1 to 6 h, the yields of 2a increased from 17 to 70 %. When the time prolonged to 9 and 12 h, the yields of 2a reached up to 97 and >99 % (Fig. 3A). With the increase of catalyst amount (based on the PMB-AZAP) from 0.13 to 0.4 mol%, the yields of 2a increased from 30 to 68 %. When the amount of catalyst was increased to 0.8 and 1.2 mol%, the yields of 2a increased to 89 and >99 %, respectively (Fig. 3B). At atmospheric pressure, the yield of 2a reached up to 90 %. When the CO2 pressure increased to 0.3 MPa, the yield of 2a was 96 %. Further increase the CO2 pressure from 0.5 to 1.0 MPa, the yields of 2a remained at >99 % (Fig. 3C). The amount of solvent also played an important role in the carboxylative cyclization reaction. Without any solvents, the yield of 2a was only 30 %, which was due to insufficient contact between Ag2O and PMB-AZAP hindering the generation of PMB-AZAP-Ag. By increasing the molar ratio of DMSO/1a to 5.6:1, 14:1 and 28:1, the yields of 2a increased to 69, 80 and >99 %, respectively. When the molar ratio of DMSO/1a reached to 42:1, the yield of 2a decreased due to the dilution of the catalyst and substrate by excessive solvents (Fig. 3D). Thus, the optimized reaction conditions were identified as 12 h, 1.2 mol% catalyst, 0.5 MPa CO2 and 28:1 molar ratio of DMSO/1a. The catalytic performance of PMB-AZAP/Ag2O was compared with the typical homogeneous transition metal (Ag, Cu, Zn, Co) catalytic systems reported in the literatures (Table S1). PMB-AZAP/Ag2O catalytic system exhibited a similar or higher catalytic activity under mild reaction conditions. The protocol by PMB-AZAP/Ag2O provided a new avenue for the efficient conversion of CO2 and production of cyclic carbonates from the viewpoints of greening and sustainable development. 2.3 Substrate generality of the carboxylative cyclization reaction The substrate generality of PMB-AZAP/Ag2O was systematically investigated (Table 2 ). 2-Ethyl-3-butynl-2-ol (1b) converted into carbonate 2b with a higher yield of 99 % under optimized conditions. Besides, various propargylic alcohols with bulky alkyl substituent including 2-isopropyl-3-butynl-2-ol (1c), 2-isobutyl-3-butynl-2-ol (1d) and 3-ethyl-4-butynl-3-ol (1e) were selected for the carboxylative cyclization, and afforded the corresponding carbonates (2c-2e) in good yields of 94–99 % by extending the reaction time. In addition, propargylic alcohols containing cyclic substituents (e.g., 1-ethynylcyclopentanol 1f, 1-ethynylcyclohexanol 1g) gave the corresponding carbonates (2f, 2g) in high yields of 96 and 97 % by extending the time to 24 h. The 2-phenyl-3-butynl-2-ol (1h) containing aromatic ring with large steric hindrance converted into 2 h with a good yield of 67 %. Secondary propargylic alcohol (3-butyn-2-ol, 1i) afforded the corresponding carbonate in a moderate yield of 42 %. Primary propargylic alcohol (prop-2-yn-1-ol, 1j) did not give any activity. The low reactivity of secondary and primary propargylic alcohols were probably because of the “gem effect” where two gem dimethyl groups favoured cyclization due to their mutual repulsion [41–43]. All the above results demonstrated PMB-AZAP/Ag2O was an efficient catalyst for the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols and CO2 at room temperature. 2.4 PMB-AZAP/Ag2O catalyzed the one-pot reaction of propargylic alcohol, CO2 and CH3OH β-Carbonyl carbonates were widely used as an intermediate in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agricultural products [44–46]. In this part, 2-butanone-3-ethyl methyl carbonate (3a) was synthesized by one-pot reaction of propargylic alcohol, CO2 and CH3OH. The one-pot reaction catalyzed by PMB-AZAP/Ag2O involved two steps, the first step was the carboxylative cyclization, and the second step was the transesterification (Table 3). When the molar ratio of CH3OH/1a was 2:1, the yields of 2a and 3a was 72 and 28 %, respectively (Entry 1). The poor yield of 3a was due to the insufficient transesterification reaction with less amount of CH3OH [47]. By further increasing the molar ratio of CH3OH/1a to 10:1 and 20:1, the yields of 3a increased to 64 and 80 % (Entry 2, 3). Continuously raising the molar ratio of CH3OH/1a to 30:1 and 50:1, the yields of 3a (74–66 %) decreased due to the dilution of the catalyst and substrate in a large amount of CH3OH (Entry 4, 5). The effect of the CO2 pressure was also investigated. At atmospheric pressure, the yield of 3a was 69 % (Entry 6). With the increase of CO2 pressure from 0.3 to 0.5 MPa, the yields (72–81 %) of 3a increased gradually since the high CO2 pressure would avoid the vaporization of CH3OH (Entry 7, Entry 3). When the CO2 pressure reached to 0.7 and 1.0 MPa, the yields of 3a basically unchanged (Entry 8, 9). When the azaphosphatranes with smaller substituents such as isobutyl and methyl combining with Ag2O, the conversions (85–92 %) of 1a and yields (38–59 %) of 3a decreased (Entry 10, 11). The difference in activity might be related to that the reaction of i-Bu-AZAP or Me-AZAP with Ag2O to form silver complexes were thermodynamically unfavorable [37]. The azaphosphatranes/Ag2O catalytic system could also efficiently catalyze the one-pot reaction to synthesize β-carbonyl carbonates. The smooth progress of the transesterification was attributed to the activation of CH3OH by the tertiary amine of PMB-AZAP (Fig. S4) [45]. 3 Conclusions In summary, we developed an efficient PMB-AZAP/Ag2O catalytic system for the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols and CO2 at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. The combination of PMB-AZAP and Ag2O with molar ratio of 0.5:1 gave α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates in the high yield of >99 %. Other azaphosphatranes with smaller substituents (i-Bu-AZAP, Me-AZAP) had a slight decrease in catalytic performance due to their unstable structure. In addition, the silver complex PMB-AZAP-Ag formed by PMB-AZAP and Ag2O during the reaction was a key active species for catalytic carboxylative cyclization reaction. The PMB-AZAP-Ag and PMB-AZAP exhibited a good synergistic catalytic effect. Moreover, PMB-AZAP/Ag2O had good substrate generality. The PMB-AZAP/Ag2O system could also catalyze the one-pot reaction of propargylic alcohol, CO2 and CH3OH, which gave the 2-butanone-3-ethyl methyl carbonate in good yield of 80 %. With the advantage of rich active sites and stable structure, the azaphosphatranes provide a new catalytic system for efficiently converting CO2 into high-value chemicals under mild conditions. 4 Experimental section The materials, characterization and synthesis of the azaphosphatranes were provided in Supporting Information (SI). 4.1 General procedure for the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols and CO2 In a typical experiment, PMB-AZAP (17 mg, 0.03 mmol), Ag2O (14 mg, 0.06 mmol), propargylic alcohol (2.5 mmol) and solvent (5 mL) were added into a 25 mL stainless teflon-lined autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer and automatic temperature controllers. The autoclave was pressurized with CO2 (0.5 MPa) and stirred for required time. After the reaction, the reactor was slowly depressurized. The reaction mixture was dissolved in acetone and analyzed by GC with biphenyl as internal standard. The pure products were isolated by column chromatography (ethyl acetate: petroleum ether = 1:9) and determined by NMR. 4.2 General procedure for the one-pot reaction of propargylic alcohol, CO2 and CH3OH In a typical experiment, PMB-AZAP (17 mg, 0.03 mmol), Ag2O (14 mg, 0.06 mmol), propargylic alcohol (2.5 mmol) and solvent (5 mL) were added into a 25 mL stainless teflon-lined autoclave equipped with magnetic stirrer and automatic temperature controllers. The autoclave was pressurized with 0.5 MPa of CO2 and stirred for required time. After the completion of the reaction, CO2 was released and CH3OH (1.6 g, 50 mmol) was added for the transesterification. The reaction mixture was then pressurized with CO2 (0.5 MPa) and stirred at 110 °C for 6 h. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature in an ice-water bath and the gas was slowly released. The reaction mixture was dissolved in acetone and analyzed by GC with biphenyl as internal standard. The pure product was isolated by column chromatography (ethyl acetate: petroleum ether = 1:9) and determined by NMR. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) to synthesize various chemicals is of great importance. Herein, various azaphosphatranes and silver salts were applied to catalyze the carboxylative cyclization of CO2 and propargylic alcohols to prepare α-methylene cyclic carbonates. The influences of catalyst structures, solvents and reaction parameters on catalytic performance were systematically studied. The combination of tris(4-methoxybenzyl) azaphosphatranes (PMB-AZAP) and Ag2O with molar ratio of 0.5:1 gave α-methylene cyclic carbonate in the yield of >99 % at room temperature. Meanwhile, other azaphosphatranes (i-Bu-AZAP, Me-AZAP) gave the product in slightly lower yields. The mechanism exploration revealed that PMB-AZAP and Ag2O formed a silver complex PMB-AZAP-Ag during the reaction, which could synergistically catalyze carboxylative cyclization reaction with PMB-AZAP, resulting in a high product yield. In contrast, AgCl or AgNO3 couldn't react with PMB-AZAP to form silver complexes, and the corresponding catalytic system had no activity. The difference of the catalytic performance indicated that PMB-AZAP-Ag was a key active species for the carboxylative cyclization reaction. The in situ NMR studies concretely demonstrated that PMB-AZAP could activate propargylic alcohols through hydrogen bonding. Furthermore, the catalytic system had good substrate generality. The PMB-AZAP/Ag2O was also applied for the one-pot reaction of propargylic alcohol, CO2 and CH3OH, affording the β-carbonyl carbonate with yield of 80 % at CH3OH/propargylic alcohols ratio of 20:1.
coredata.dc:title: Azaphosphatrane/Ag2O catalyzed the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols and CO2
